results.title: Succession on lava
results.creator_credit: Bert Van Bork and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biology program; unit 1. Ecology”
Illustrates the destruction caused by a volcanic eruption in Hawaii, and examines the difficulties encountered by the first forms of life that re-appear. Traces the stages of ecological succession, from the blue-green algae to the re-establishment of a mature biotic community.

results.title: Succession from sand dune to forest
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biology program; unit 1. Ecology”.
Explains that succession is the process by which a given area changes slowly and continuously until it finally becomes a stable community. Shows one of the earliest and most thoroughly studied examples of this process on the shore of Lake Michigan

results.title: Give sharks a chance
results.creator_credit: Richard Dennison, National Geographic Society, John Gau Productions and Orana Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Blue wilderness”.
After a series of shark attacks on the Gold Coast, Ron and Valerie Taylor, try to curb an outbreak of hysteria, and take a group of people, including two shark attack victims, to confront the object of their fears face to face.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Richard Dennison, National Geographic Society, John Gau Productions and Orana Films

results.title: The Sea
results.creator_credit: Michael Birch and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biology program; unit 1. Ecology”.
Illustrates basic concepts of marine ecology, and shows the interrelationship between living things in the sea, their dependence on each other and on the conditions of the marine environment. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Population ecology
results.creator_credit: Stanley Croner and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biology program; unit 1. Ecology”.
Shows how environmental conditions such as natural enemies and food factors can help increase or reduce births and deaths. Discusses how humans have created the birth surplus over death called the population explosion. Suitable for upper secondary level.

Episode of Series “Biology program; unit 1. Ecology”.

results.title: Shadow on the reef. Turning turtle.
results.creator_credit: Richard Dennison, ABC-TV (Australia), National Geographic Society and Orana Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Blue wilderness”.
“Shadow on the reef” looks at the incredible Whale Shark, the world’s largest shark. Valerie and Ron Taylor explore the wonders of the deep below the coral reef, emphasising the message that this fragile ecology is increasingly under threat.
“Turning Turtle” sees Ron and Valerie Taylor at odds with the Queensland Government over the fate of turtles on coral islands, with a focus on Raine Island. The Green Turtles are a rare and ancient species and the fight to save them pits the Taylors against bureaucracy and harsh physical conditions.
